I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.    The long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
(Strategy 2020) highlights the need for ADB to promote partnerships and knowledge solutions 
as drivers of change for its new development agenda.1 Strategy 2020 has adopted a vision of 
Asia and the Pacific free of poverty. This is to be achieved by making growth and social 
development  more  inclusive,  and  through  emphasis  on  environmental  sustainability  and 
regional cooperation. It sees ADB as playing a much bigger role in knowledge development, 
exchanges,  and  partnerships.  The  regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance            
(R-CDTA) will facilitate the development and exchange of new knowledge on poverty and 
inclusive growth between leading knowledge institutions and policy makers in Asia, through 
capacity-building support and the use of modern communication and technology solutions.2 It 
will establish a regional knowledge forum that exchanges knowledge through an Asia-wide 
poverty and inclusive growth website, and will partner with other international agencies for this 
purpose.3  
II.  ISSUES 
2.    Remaining and New Challenges in Reducing Poverty. Asia and the Pacific is known 
for  its  success  in  the  last  decade  in  reducing  income  poverty  and  enhancing  social 
development. However, new poverty estimates indicate that the incidence and magnitude of 
poverty is larger than previous estimates, and that poverty reduction may not be as successful 
as  formerly  considered.4 Major  challenges  remain,  therefore,  and  new  ones  are  arising 
particularly with regard to (i) non-income dimensions of poverty and the achievement of the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs); (ii) aggravation of poverty caused by environmental 
factors and climate change; (iii) challenges in providing effective social protection, including 
issues related to demographic change, aging, and migration; and (iv) recent reversals of poverty 
reduction caused by food price increases. 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2  The  R-CDTA  concept  was  approved  by  the  Vice-President,  Knowledge  Management  and  Sustainable 
Development on 6 March 2007. Funding from the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund was 
endorsed on 4 October 2007. Additional funding from the People’s Republic of China (PRC) Regional Cooperation 
and Poverty Reduction Fund was approved on 24 June 2008. The R-CDTA was first listed in the business 
opportunities section of the ADB website on 10 July 2008. 
3  The R-CDTA will support, among others, the work of the ADB–United Nations Economic and Social Commission 
for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP)–United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) partnership to achieve the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs); and regional discussion on poverty and inclusive growth in the context of 
ASEAN+3.  It  will  also  link  with  the  Global  Development  Network  and  other  internet-based  and  electronic 
knowledge-sharing institutions and tools. The approach taken in this R-CDTA differs from such networks by 
focusing on poverty (not broader development) issues in Asia only; and by institutionalizing knowledge exchanges 
between leading regional and national knowledge centers on poverty reduction (these centers will be close to the 
government, rather than being individual researchers).

2   
3.    Weaknesses  in  Knowledge  Sharing.  Asian  experiences  in  poverty  reduction  are 
diverse, and countries are increasingly interested in learning from each other and sharing their 
experiences. However, a number of factors are hampering efficient exchange of knowledge. 
First, there are insufficient knowledge products in an appropriate form for facilitating knowledge 
exchanges. While much data and research on successful experiences and good practices exist, 
including from ADB’s own operational experience, they are not available in an easily shareable 
form (i.e., synthesized, succinct, and high-quality form; and in common [English] language) for 
usage beyond academic circles and across borders. As a result, such knowledge is often not 
sufficiently  replicated  (with  suitable  local  adaptations),  or  upgraded.  Secondly,  while  many 
countries  have  leading  knowledge  and  policy  research  institutions,  their  research  is  often 
disseminated in a limited manner with insufficient influence in international policy discussions. 
Encouraging them to develop appropriate shareable knowledge products and bringing them 
together in knowledge exchange networks will boost knowledge sharing in the region. Finally, 
knowledge exchange modalities (especially across borders) are weak and sporadic, and are not 
being conducted systematically. ADB is in a unique position, with membership embracing all 
these countries, to facilitate such exchanges. Regional groupings, such as the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, can 
also play an important role in sharing information for policy implementation.  
4.    Inadequate Use of Information and Communication Technology within Knowledge 
Networks.  To  share  both  regional  and  local  knowledge  widely,  quickly,  efficiently,  and 
inexpensively, the R-CDTA will promote the use of modern electronic networks and information 
and communication technology (ICT) such as websites, e-newsletters, teleconferencing, and 
videoconferencing.  This  will  address  some  lessons  from  past  ADB  support  to  knowledge 
networks,  which  was  less  sustainable  beyond  the  financing  of  studies  and  conferences. 
Maximizing use of ICT for networking purposes is also environment-friendly as it will reduce 
conferences and air travel to the minimum.   
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.    The Project is expected to improve—through knowledge sharing—strategic thinking on 
poverty reduction and inclusive growth. It will generate and share—in a regional context—
knowledge products in these areas. Through its regional website, it will institutionalize a regional 
knowledge network on poverty reduction for Asia and the Pacific.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Components 
a.  Developing Knowledge Products  
6.    Support will be provided to (i) help national think tank institutions in the region develop 
knowledge products related to poverty and inclusive growth, and synthesize such products for 
sharing; and (ii) develop and share knowledge products from ADB’s own experience. 
7.    Knowledge Products of Regional Knowledge Institutions. The R-CDTA will help 
synthesize knowledge on new poverty reduction and inclusive growth issues in Asia and the 
Pacific, and make such knowledge more easily accessible to domestic and regional experts and 
policy  makers.  To  this  end,  it  will  finance—through  the  selected  regional  knowledge 
institutions—about 34 policy briefs and working papers and a number of studies on issues of 
regional interest. In addition, it is expected that the participating research institutions will share 
about 70 knowledge papers from their own work, and place them on their websites within the R-

3
CDTA implementation period. The R-CDTA will not finance new original research;5 rather, it will 
summarize and share—through a regional website—existing national knowledge. A tentative list 
of topics that have been initially considered is in Appendix 3. The topics of working papers and 
policy briefs, and the contribution of individual countries, will be mutually agreed upon at the 
beginning of R-CDTA implementation by the four participating subregional network partners and 
ADB staff.  
8.    Knowledge  Products  of  ADB.  The  R-CDTA  will  also  support  the  preparation  of 
knowledge products based on ADB’s experience to enable it to share its own operational 
experiences  on  poverty  and  inclusive  growth  more  effectively.  This  will  be  achieved  by 
supporting preparation of eight policy briefs and seven working papers, and publishing them 
through an e-newsletter on poverty and inclusive growth.6   
b.  Facilitating Knowledge Networks 
9.    The R-CDTA will build capacities in the selected knowledge institutions to improve and 
maintain their own websites better as an effective means to share relevant knowledge on 
poverty reduction and inclusive growth. These websites will then be linked to the relevant 
websites  of  participating  national  think  tank  institutions  by  establishing  similar  content 
structures. In addition, the national websites will be linked to each other, thereby establishing a 
regional  website  on  poverty  reduction  and  inclusive  growth  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  The 
International Poverty Reduction Center in China (IPRCC) 7 will serve as a hub for poverty 
networks in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and coordinate subregional activities with 
poverty  networks  in  Central  Asia.  The  National  Council  of  Applied  Economic  Research 
(NCAER) will serve as a hub for the poverty networks in India, and coordinate subregional 
activities with poverty networks in South Asia. The Korean Development Institute (KDI) will 
coordinate work in the Republic of Korea, and the Philippine Institute for Development Studies 
(PIDS) will coordinate subregional activities with poverty networks in Southeast Asia and the 
Pacific.  The  regional  network  will  also  be  linked  to  the  poverty  and  MDG  websites  of 
international institutions such as ADB, the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for 
Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP), and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) 
already established under the regional partnership on MDGs;8 and to other relevant sections of 
international websites and electronic newsletters as needed.9 Overall, the R-CDTA will partner

PADI initiative. IPRCC has requested ADB support to strengthen its interaction with other poverty research 
institutions in the region. The R-CDTA will build capacities in IPRCC for strengthening its role as an Asia-wide 
international institution and as secretariat for PADI.

4   
finally  with  about  50 national  and  regional  knowledge  institutions,  government  agencies, 
regional associations, and development institutions. The regional website network will thus be a 
unique knowledge database on all poverty reduction strategic approaches, sector and thematic 
thinking, country programs and experiences, analytical tools, and knowledge exchange in Asia 
and the Pacific. 
10.   Furthermore,  the  R-CDTA  will  facilitate  regional  exchanges  through  two  regional 
conferences  (both  supported  under  this  R-CDTA)  and  three  policy  seminars;  it  intends  to 
conduct much of such exchanges through videoconferencing, for which some limited support 
will be provided to the institutions. Such regional exchanges will include the participation of 
regional  groupings  such  as  ASEAN;10 and  linkages  with  the  new  Poverty  Analysis  and 
Development Initiative (PADI),11 and the MDG partnership of ADB with UNESCAP and UNDP.12  
11.   With  parallel  financing  from  the  ASEAN  Foundation,  through  the  Asian  Institute  of 
Management (AIM), the R-CDTA will also facilitate specific capacity building for governments on 
the opportunities of closer private sector involvement in poverty reduction. 
2.  Sustainability  
12.   Regional  knowledge  exchange  requires  up-front  development  of  capacities,  e.g.,  in 
establishing shared information through websites and e-newsletters and in building up networks. 
The  R-CDTA  will  provide  initial  support  for  development  of  knowledge  products  and  for 
networking. Once such networks are established, such built-up capacity will be maintained by 
the participating institutions over time, with a much smaller role (such as supporting workshops 
and  help  populating  the  regional  website)  correspondingly  for  ADB.  The  R-CDTA  will  be 
implemented in two phases. Initially, it will support knowledge institutions in PRC, India, and the 
Republic of Korea to develop knowledge products; and strengthen their capacities to undertake 
knowledge exchanges facilitated by the use of ICT and improved websites. In the second 
phase, it will bring in other subregional knowledge institutions in Asia and the Pacific within the 
knowledge network.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.   The R-CDTA, estimated to cost $1,000,000, will be jointly financed on a grant basis by 
the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and the People’s Republic of 
China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund, both administered by ADB.13 In 
                                                                                                                                                          
Poverty and Economic Policy Research Network, and selected other poverty centers outside Asia and the Pacific, 
especially in Africa and Latin America.  
10  One policy seminar, cosponsored by the ASEAN Foundation, will specifically focus on the role of regional 
institutions for poverty reduction in Southeast Asia.  
11 PADI is a regional forum established by the World Bank Institute in 2001 for sharing poverty data, poverty 
research, and poverty policy in East Asia. IPRCC is currently the secretariat of the PADI knowledge network. The 
institution is currently being reformed to serve as a regional network on poverty analysis, policy influencing, 
knowledge sharing and data and indicators exchange. PADI is currently being transformed from a Poverty and 
Data Initiative to a Poverty Analysis and Development Initiative, with stronger country ownership and focus on 
capacity building for three pillars, i.e. poverty data and indicators; policy influencing; and poverty research.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.   Executing and Implementing Agencies. ADB, through the Poverty Unit in the Regional 
and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) will be the Executing Agency; and will be 
responsible for overall management and coordination, including monitoring the agreements with 
the participating institutions and timely completion of outputs and activities. IPRCC, NCAER, 
KDI, and PIDS will be the coordinating implementing agencies. They will work with other leading 
national  think  tank  and  government  institutions  as  well  as  subregional  bodies  and 
organizations.15 ADB will set up an internal peer review group and involve its poverty network to 
advise on the R-CDTA from the perspectives of regional and other knowledge departments. 
15.   Expanding Networking through Phased Approach. The R-CDTA will adopt a phased 
approach to expanding the network. In the first year, it will work—through IPRCC, KDI and 
NCAER —with national research institutions in PRC, India, and the Republic of Korea. In the 
second and third years, the coverage of the network will gradually be increased after lessons 
from the first phase are internalized. In the second phase, it is envisaged that (i) IPRCC will also 
cover knowledge networks in Central Asia; (ii) NCAER will cover poverty knowledge networks in 
South Asia; and (iii) PIDS, to be included in the second phase, will coordinate knowledge 
exchange in Southeast Asia and the Pacific. The ASEAN Foundation has also provided parallel 
financing to this R-CDTA to support PIDS and AIM in activities for Southeast Asia. AIM and 
PIDS will facilitate capacity building for senior government officials involved in poverty reduction, 
on  private  sector  and  civil  society  involvement  in  poverty  reduction;  and  prepare  specific 
recommendations for ASEAN’s role in regional poverty reduction. Appendix 3 gives an overview 
of likely participating agencies. 
16.   Consultants and Other Input Requirements. The R-CDTA will require an estimated 
53 person-months of international and 146 person-months of national consulting services to 
help develop capacity in the knowledge institutions. All consultants will be engaged on an 
individual basis and not through a firm. The national and international consultants financed by 
ADB under this R-CDTA will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  research  networks  (IPRCC,  KDI, 
NCAER, and PIDS) will engage national consultants from different countries under their own 
institutional  arrangements  in  accordance  with  the  above-mentioned  ADB  guidelines.  The 
consultants  supporting  development  of  knowledge  products  will  be  economists  with 
specialization in development economics who have worked in areas of poverty reduction and 
inclusive growth and sustainable development. Consultants needed for website development 
and management will have expertise in knowledge management, website coordination and 
management, web writing, and summarizing strategic policy briefs in poverty reduction. The 
outline terms of reference of the consultants and participating institutions are in Appendix 4.16 
17.   Time  Frame.  The  R-CDTA  will  be  implemented  over  3  years  (November  2008–
December 2011). Cooperation on subregional knowledge hubs for Central Asia, South Asia, 
and  Southeast  Asia  will  commence  after  15  months  of  R-CDTA  implementation.  The 
international poverty and inclusive growth website is expected to be online by May 2009 and 
updated on a monthly basis. The electronic newsletters (including that focusing on ADB work) 
will appear bimonthly starting in the first quarter of 2009. Series of research report summaries

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
18.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund; and (ii) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction 
Fund for Regional Knowledge and Partnership Networks for Poverty Reduction and Inclusive 
Growth, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Source: ADB estimates.

10    Appendix 3 
KNOWLEDGE NETWORKS AND KNOWLEDGE PRODUCTS 
 
1.    Initially, the regional capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) will work with three 
knowledge networks in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), India, and the Republic of Korea. In the 
second phase (years 2–3), these knowledge networks will also work with other knowledge centers in 
Central Asia, South Asia, and Southeast Asia. 
(i)  The International Poverty Reduction Center in China (IPRCC) in Beijing will coordinate 
activities with other research networks and government agencies in the PRC and Central 
Asia.  
(ii)  The National Council for Applied Economic Research (NCAER) in New Delhi will be a hub 
for knowledge exchange on poverty reduction and inclusive growth in India, and coordinate 
knowledge exchange with South Asia. 
(iii) The Korean Development Institute (KDI) will coordinate knowledge exchange on poverty 
reduction and inclusive growth in the Republic of Korea. 
(iv) The  Philippine  Institute  for  Development  Studies  (PIDS)  will  coordinate  knowledge 
exchange on poverty reduction and inclusive growth with the research network in East and 
Southeast Asia (excluding PRC, the Republic of Korea, and Mongolia), and the Pacific.  
 
2.    In total, the R-CDTA will partner with about 50 national and regional knowledge institutions 
(including  government  agencies,  regional  associations,  research  organizations,  and  development 
institutions). The institutional setup of the R-CDTA is shown in Figure A3. 
 
3.    The participating institutions will produce various knowledge products, especially summary 
papers and policy briefs. The list of topics to be taken up in each round, leading to discussion during 
the conferences and seminars, will be decided by a small independent group in consultation with the 
four main knowledge coordinating institutions and a peer review group within the Asian Development 
Bank. A tentative list of areas for developing knowledge products includes 
(i)  inclusiveness of growth, including income and spatial inequalities; 
(ii)  implications of climate change on the poor, and the environments of poverty; 
(iii)  social protection and inclusion; 
(iv)  tracking food and fuel price increases and hunger; 
(v)  innovation in social protection for the poor and for aging societies; 
(vi)  approaches and challenges to meeting the MDGs in Asia; 
(vii)  the poverty reduction agenda for emerging middle income countries in Asia; 
(viii)  demand analysis in selected countries in the region on what they want to learn from 
poverty reduction in the PRC (country studies plus summary paper); and 
(ix)  policy  recommendation  on  the  role  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations 
(ASEAN) and other regional institutions for poverty reduction in the region.

12    Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Summary 
1.    A total of 53 person-months of international and 146 person-months of national consulting 
services will be provided under the technical assistance. Of this, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
will directly contract the international consultants and 13 person-months of national consultants. In 
addition, ADB will engage into an output-based contract arrangement with the International Poverty 
Reduction Center in China (IPRCC), National Council for Applied Economic Research (NCAER), 
Korean Development Institute (KDI), and Philippine Institute for Development Studies (PIDS), which 
will then engage national consultants from various countries to prepare policy briefs and working 
papers.  
2.    In total, the regional capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) will produce about 
139 knowledge contributions for the poverty website. These contributions will be directly financed 
through the R-CDTA; the remainder will be financed through sharing from the participating knowledge 
centers. The   R-CDTA will facilitate two conferences and four seminars, establish a regional website 
on  poverty  reduction,  and  promote  the  sharing  of  information  through  a  series  of  10  electronic 
newsletters  and  12 issues  of  ADB’s  Poverty  Matters  newsletter.  A  detailed  list  of  outputs  and 
respective cost estimates for the various participating institutions is in Supplementary Appendix E.  
3.    The national consultants will (i) assist the knowledge hubs in preparing policy briefs and 
working papers and in making those relevant for website and e-newsletter publication, (ii) help ADB in 
designing an e-newsletter, and (iii) assist the regional knowledge hub design its website and e-
newsletter. The international consultants will (i) help the regional network setting up, populating, and 
maintaining  a  website  and  a  newsletter  that  are  content-based  and  shared  nationally  and 
internationally;  and  (ii) assist  ADB  in  preparing  policy  briefs  and  working  papers,  and  editing 
conference documents for publication. The consultants will be recruited individually by ADB according 
to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). ADB will approve 
the terms of reference and the ranked short list of candidates hired by the national knowledge hubs. 
B.  Terms of Reference 
1.  Consultants Hired by ADB 
4.    Poverty  Reduction  and  Inclusive  Growth  Economist  and  Knowledge  Manager 
(international,  16  person-months).  The  poverty  reduction  and  inclusive  growth  economist  and 
knowledge  manager  will  be  hired  for  16  person-months  over  36  months.  He  or  she  will  work 
intermittently for about 8 months in the first year, 5 months in the second year, and 3 months in the 
third year of cooperation. The expert will work from their home office. Up to seven regional trips will be 
required for closer coordination with ADB, IPRCC, and NCAER, as well as possible participation in the 
regional conferences. The consultant will be an economist with specific international knowledge in 
poverty reduction and inclusive growth, as well as good experience in website and e-newsletter 
writing.  He  or  she  needs  to  have  good  communication  and  negotiation  skills  and  shall  be 
internationally well known to research networks in Asia working on poverty reduction. Under the 
supervision of ADB and in close cooperation with IPRCC, the consultant will do the following. 
(i)  Serve as overall coordinator and knowledge manager for the R-CDTA. 
(ii) Build up capacities in IPRCC to serve as the regional knowledge center on poverty and 
inclusive  growth  in  Asia;  establish  contact  and  working  relations  with  Asian  regional 
associations; and facilitate, through IPRCC as the secretariat for the new Poverty Analysis

Appendix 4  13 
 
and Development Initiative (PADI), cooperation with PADI as the regional knowledge forum 
on poverty. 
(iii) Establish linkages to relevant poverty websites in Asia, and connect them to the Asia 
Poverty and Inclusive growth website established under this R-CDTA, provide content  for 
designing and managing the regional website and the Poverty Matters newsletter, and 
coordinate the final design with ADB, the web designer, and the participating regional 
network institutions (i.e., IPRCC, KDI, NCAER, and PIDS); advise regional and national 
centers on linking their poverty website and contents to the regional website.  
(iv) Assist the regional knowledge hubs in preparing policy briefs and working papers and in 
making  those  relevant  for  website  and  e-newsletter  publication;  edit  policy  briefs  and 
working papers and make them ready for website and e-newsletter publishing; write, on a 
selective basis, own policy briefs and working papers; serve as economics editor and 
adviser to the contents of participating institutions’ websites.  
5.    Designer for electronic media (national, 4 person-months). The designer for the regional 
Poverty and Inclusive Growth website and the Poverty Matters e-newsletter designer will be a national 
consultant  (or  firm)  hired  by  ADB  in  the  Philippines  or  other  developing  member  country.  The 
consultant  shall  have  expertise  in  website  design  for  international  development  institutions  and 
poverty websites. Experience with ADB in this matter is an advantage. The work will be done from 
head office but teleconferencing and videoconferencing with ADB and IPRCC are envisaged. Under 
the supervision of ADB, the consultant will  
(i)  develop the regional poverty and inclusive growth website in close cooperation with ADB, 
IPRCC, and the poverty reduction knowledge manager; assist ADB and IPRCC in other 
technical website and newsletter-related issues during the first 3 months of actual rollout; 
and provide backup support; 
(ii)  identify the most efficient and effective international room space and arrange for technical 
solutions to place the website in such web-room;17 
(iii)  develop the e-newsletter based on the design and conceptual inputs from the poverty 
reduction knowledge manager, ADB, and IPRCC; and 
(iv)  establish technical connectivity to other poverty websites in the region and between the 
participating regional knowledge hubs. 
6.    Development  Economics  Editor  (international, 12 person-months). An economics editor 
(poverty reduction economist) will work with the knowledge manager, ADB, and IPRCC intermittently 
over 3 years from his or her home office on the regional poverty and inclusive growth e-newsletter. 
Under the supervision of ADB, the consultant will 
(i)  check the regular updates of the ADB poverty websites and propose to ADB interesting 
features for the Poverty Matters newsletter; 
(ii)  write overview and reference articles for the Poverty Matters newsletter; 
                                                 
17  The website has to be physically placed on a server equipped for sharing information internationally. The space for the 
website needs to be leased from that server. The designer will assist ADB in selecting the proper roomspace and 
discussing the terms and conditions.

14    Appendix 4 
(iii)  write summaries for the e-newsletter in cooperation with the knowledge manager and ADB; 
and 
(iv)  edit news and articles provided by the knowledge manager and ADB and make them “web 
ready.” 
7.    Poverty  and  Inclusive  Growth  Specialists  (international,  26  person-months).  Various 
specialists will be hired by ADB to prepare at least 10 policy briefs and 8 working papers on poverty 
and inclusive growth topics, based on ADB examples. The contents will be determined by ADB and 
separate terms of reference will be provided for each paper.  
8.    Copy Editor for Conference Proceedings (international, 5 person-months). A copy editor will 
be engaged to make the proceedings of two conferences ready for final publication. The copy editor 
shall  work  closely  with  the  conference  organizers  (IPRCC,  NCAER,  and  KDI);  the  knowledge 
manager; and ADB. 
2.  Knowledge Cooperation with the Network Hubs 
9.    ADB will engage in output-based contractual arrangements with KDI, NCAER, IPRCC, and 
PIDS to cover the cooperation expenditures of those institutions related to this R-CDTA. Among 
others, the four knowledge networks will  
(i)  engage,  in  close  cooperation  with  national  poverty  knowledge  institutions,  national 
consultants and supervise their work on preparing policy briefs and working papers as well 
as opinion pieces;  
(ii)  stimulate, in cooperation with national and subregional poverty institutions, the writing of at 
least 30 additional working papers and additional policy briefs for the poverty website 
through national knowledge institutions, to be shared on the regional poverty website; 
(iii)  coordinate linking the websites of participating national institutions with the regional website 
to be developed under this R-CDTA; 
(iv)  coordinate,  as  subregional  knowledge  coordinator,  with  institutions  in  the  respective 
subregions and help them in aligning their poverty websites; formalize the cooperation with 
national knowledge institutions through simple contractual arrangements (letters of intent); 
(v)  engage regional e-newsletter writers to prepare articles (including translations into English, 
if necessary) for the national and regional websites; 
(vi)  organize  international  conferences  and  policy  seminar  in  close  cooperation  with  ADB, 
PADI, and regional associations; and 
(vii) prepare annual progress reports; 
10.   In addition, IPRCC will serve as regional anchor for the R-CDTA. In this function, it will prepare 
progress reports and closely work with the knowledge manager.
